textSections.title: Feedback Prioritization Framework
textSections.content:
**Step 1: Categorize all feedback**

| Category | Description | Timeline |
|----------|-------------|----------|
| üö® Critical Bugs | App crashes, data loss, security issues | Fix immediately |
| üêõ Minor Bugs | UI glitches, broken links, typos | Batch and fix weekly |
| ‚ö° Quick Wins | Small improvements, < 2 hours work | Do 2-3 per week |
| ‚ú® Features | New functionality users requested | Plan for next version |
| üí≠ Nice-to-Haves | 'Would be cool if...' ideas | Backlog, maybe later |

**Step 2: Apply the ICE Framework**

For each feature/improvement, score 1-10 on:
- **Impact:** How much will this improve the product?
- **Confidence:** How sure are you this is the right solution?
- **Ease:** How easy is this to implement?

ICE Score = (Impact √ó Confidence √ó Ease) / 3

Prioritize highest ICE scores first.

**Step 3: Create a Simple Roadmap**

**This Week:**
- [ ] Fix critical bug: [describe]
- [ ] Quick win: [describe]
- [ ] Quick win: [describe]

**Next 2 Weeks:**
- [ ] Feature: [describe]
- [ ] Minor bugs batch fix

**Next Month:**
- [ ] Major feature: [describe]
- [ ] Performance optimization

**Future Backlog:**
- [Nice-to-have ideas]

Review and update weekly based on new feedback.

textSections.title: How to Ask Questions That Get Answered
textSections.content:
**The MCVE Principle: Minimal, Complete, Verifiable Example**

‚ùå Bad Question:
'My app doesn't work. Help!'

‚úÖ Good Question:

**Title:** Next.js deployment fails on Vercel with 'Module not found' error

**Context:**
I'm deploying a Next.js 14 app to Vercel. It works locally but fails during build.

**What I tried:**
1. Checked package.json ‚Äî all dependencies listed
2. Ran `npm run build` locally ‚Äî succeeds
3. Cleared Vercel cache and redeployed ‚Äî same error

**Error message:**
```
Error: Cannot find module '@/components/Header'
```

**Relevant code:**
```typescript
// app/page.tsx
import Header from '@/components/Header';
```

**Question:**
Is this a case-sensitivity issue? My local file is `header.tsx` not `Header.tsx`. Does Vercel's Linux environment treat this differently?

---

**Why this works:**
- Specific, searchable title
- Clear context (what, where, when)
- Shows what you already tried
- Includes actual error message
- Provides relevant code
- Proposes a hypothesis

This gets answered in minutes, not hours.

textSections.title: Developer Communities for AI Builders
textSections.content:
**Claude & Anthropic:**
- Official Discord: [discord.gg/anthropic]
- Anthropic Community Forum: [community.anthropic.com]
- Twitter/X: Follow @AnthropicAI, #ClaudeAI

**02Ship Community:**
- Discord: https://discord.gg/btqaA3hzKp
- GitHub Discussions: https://github.com/bobjiang/zero-to-ship/discussions
- Share your projects, get feedback, find collaborators

**General AI/No-Code Building:**
- r/ClaudeAI (Reddit)
- r/ChatGPT (Reddit)
- r/ArtificialIntelligence (Reddit)
- Indie Hackers: [indiehackers.com]
- Product Hunt: [producthunt.com]

**Tech-Specific:**
- Next.js Discord: For Next.js questions
- Vercel Community: Deployment help
- Supabase Discord: Database/backend

**Local Communities:**
- Check Meetup.com for AI/tech meetups in your city
- Attend hackathons ‚Äî great for learning and networking

**How to engage:**
1. Lurk for a week to understand the culture
2. Introduce yourself in the #introductions channel
3. Ask thoughtful questions (use MCVE principle)
4. Answer questions you know the answer to
5. Share your wins and learnings
6. Don't spam, don't self-promote without adding value

textSections.title: When Claude Can't Help: Escalation Strategies
textSections.content:
**Situation 1: Claude gives wrong/outdated information**
‚Üí Check official documentation (docs.anthropic.com, framework docs)
‚Üí Search GitHub issues for your specific error
‚Üí Ask in community with 'Claude suggested X, but Y happened'

**Situation 2: Claude doesn't understand your domain**
‚Üí Provide more context via Projects (upload domain-specific docs)
‚Üí Break the problem into smaller pieces
‚Üí Consult a domain expert (human)

**Situation 3: Complex debugging beyond Claude's scope**
‚Üí Use traditional debugging tools (browser DevTools, logging)
‚Üí Rubber duck debugging (explain the problem out loud)
‚Üí Pair with a developer (remotely or in-person)

**Situation 4: You need human judgment**
‚Üí Design decisions: Ask in design communities (Dribbble, Designer News)
‚Üí Business decisions: Talk to potential users, not Claude
‚Üí Ethical questions: Consult ethics guidelines or human advisors

**Situation 5: Performance or scaling issues**
‚Üí Use profiling tools (Lighthouse, Vercel Analytics)
‚Üí Consult performance-specific resources (web.dev)
‚Üí Consider hiring a specialist for complex optimization

**General rule:**
Claude is great for 80% of building. For the other 20%, lean on:
- Official documentation
- Human communities
- Specialized tools
- Your own judgment

textSections.title: Building in Public: A Strategy for Accountability
textSections.content:
**What is Building in Public?**
Sharing your progress, challenges, and learnings publicly (Twitter, blog, Discord) as you build.

**Benefits:**
- Accountability: Public commitment motivates consistency
- Feedback: Early users find you and give input
- Network: Connect with other builders
- Portfolio: Your journey becomes your resume
- Learning: Teaching others solidifies your knowledge

**What to share:**
- Weekly updates: What you shipped, what you learned
- Challenges: 'Stuck on X, tried Y and Z' (often gets help)
- Wins: 'First 10 users!' (people celebrate with you)
- Metrics: 'Traffic doubled this week!'
- Lessons: 'Learned that X doesn't work, trying Y instead'

**Where to share:**
- Twitter/X: Short updates, screenshots, metrics
- LinkedIn: Professional angle, project milestones
- Dev.to or Hashnode: Longer blog posts, tutorials
- Discord/Slack communities: Daily check-ins
- YouTube/Loom: Screen recordings of features

**How often:**
- Daily: Quick wins or progress notes (optional)
- Weekly: Summary of what shipped
- Monthly: Bigger reflections, metrics, roadmap

**What NOT to share:**
- Proprietary code or trade secrets
- User data or private information
- Unvalidated ideas you're protective of (unless you want feedback)

**Example weekly update template:**

üöÄ Week 12 of building [Your Product]

Shipped:
‚úÖ Feature X
‚úÖ Bug fixes (list)

Learned:
üí° Lesson about [topic]

Next week:
üéØ Goal 1
üéØ Goal 2

Link: [yourproduct.com]

#BuildInPublic #IndieHacker

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Roadmap:** A plan showing what features/improvements you'll build and when

**Technical Debt:** Code that works but is messy/inefficient and will slow you down later

**Pivot:** Changing your product direction based on what you learned

**Iteration:** Incremental improvement cycles (ship ‚Üí learn ‚Üí improve ‚Üí repeat)

**Backlog:** A list of ideas/features you might build someday (not committed)

**Building in Public:** Sharing your product development journey publicly

**MCVE:** Minimal, Complete, Verifiable Example ‚Äî best way to ask technical questions

commonMistakes.mistake: Trying to build every requested feature
commonMistakes.explanation: Most requests aren't needed by most users. Prioritize ruthlessly.
Vague questions get ignored. Use the MCVE principle for fast, helpful answers.

commonMistakes.mistake: Working in isolation without sharing progress
commonMistakes.explanation: You miss valuable feedback and accountability. Build in public or join communities.

commonMistakes.mistake: Giving up after the first user criticism
commonMistakes.explanation: Negative feedback is data, not a personal attack. Iterate based on patterns, not one-offs.

commonMistakes.mistake: Planning 6 months ahead for a 2-week-old product
commonMistakes.explanation: Your roadmap will change constantly. Plan 2-4 weeks out, not months.

reflectionQuestions: What's the one piece of feedback you've received that you're most excited to implement? Why?
Think about a time you got stuck on a problem. What helped you get unstuck? How can you apply that strategy again?
If you had to pick just one improvement to ship next week, what would have the biggest impact on your users?

exercises.title: Prioritize Your Roadmap
exercises.description: Collect all feedback and feature ideas for your project, categorize them, and create a prioritized roadmap for the next 4 weeks.
exercises.output: A roadmap document showing: categorized feedback (bugs, quick wins, features), ICE scores for top 5 items, and a 4-week plan
successCriteria: Collected at least 5 pieces of feedback (real or hypothetical)
Categorized each item (critical, minor bug, quick win, feature, nice-to-have)
Scored top 5 items using ICE framework
Created a concrete 4-week plan with specific tasks
Identified at least one thing you're NOT going to build (and why)

exercises.title: Ask a Great Question
exercises.description: Identify a problem you're currently facing, then craft a well-formatted question and post it in a relevant community.
exercises.output: A posted question (screenshot or link) following MCVE principles, plus documentation of the response you received
successCriteria: Chose an appropriate community for your question
Question includes: clear title, context, what you tried, error message/code, hypothesis
Actually posted (not just drafted) the question
Waited for and documented the response (even if it takes a day)
Followed up with 'this worked!' or clarifying questions

exercises.title: Build in Public - Week 1
exercises.description: Share your project and progress publicly for one week using at least two platforms.
exercises.output: A summary of your week including: what you shared, where you shared it, engagement you received, and what you learned
successCriteria: Shared on at least 2 platforms (Twitter, LinkedIn, Discord, Dev.to, etc.)
Posted at least 3 updates throughout the week (start, mid, end)
Included at least one screenshot, metric, or demo
Engaged with at least 2 other builders' posts
Reflected on how public accountability affected your motivation

Meta celebration: By completing this course, students are now part of the AI builder community ‚Äî welcome them officially!
